text: This transmits new text and Table of Contents for IRM 6.332.1 Workforce Recruitment Strategy, Section 1, Objectives, Responsibilities, and Authorities.

The purpose of this IRM is to establish general principles, concepts, and policies that govern strategic recruitment activities within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). These requirements constitute the framework for the recruitment and employment marketing activities of the IRS Recruitment Office.
NATURE OF MATERIAL

This IRM reflects the role of the IRS Recruitment Office in meeting the overarching recruitment goals of the IRS. It includes policy and guidance on strategic recruitment activities ranging from marketing materials and campaigns (print, radio, television, and Internet) to recruitment activities and strategy. This IRM also establishes the relationship between the IRS Recruiting Office and other IRS operating divisions and functional units.

Recruitment Strategies
) IRM
provides information on the IRS Recruiting Office, within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Human Capital Office. (

) The IRS’s integrated recruitment strategy allows the Service to allocate resources to recruiting campaigns and activities that support the Service’s of Strategic of building and maintaining a diverse high quality workforce. The IRS ment Office centralizes recruitment activities to ensure a consistent and consistent quality. (
) The mission of the IRS Recruitment Office (IRO) is to support the IRS ment goal of attracting the best candidates for IRS positions. Office (

) The IRO will support its mission by managing an organization-wide strategy that supports and balances all division and functional unit hiring needs, includes consistent messaging and enables decentralized, based strategic execution to, ensure regional relationships with recruiting sources and field and campus ownership of local recruiting efforts. (
) The IRO mission has been informed by the OPM publication Building and Maintaining a Diverse and High Quality Workforce, a guide for Federal agencies (opm.gov/diversity/guide.htm). (
) The IRO will accomplish its mission by: (cid:

) Establishing a data-driven annual recruiting plan, to include a single set Office Service-wide recruiting targets. Targeted recruitment efforts (i.e., and locations and/or candidates segments) will be based on long-term workforce needs and the efficient use of resources, and the annual ment plan will ensure EDI and diversity considerations are addressed. (cid:

) Partnering directly with all operating divisions and functional units HCO, EDI and IRS affinity groups to ensure that all recruitment efforts incorporated or reflected in the corporate recruitment strategy. (cid:

) Strategically managing relationships with key contacts at gateway institu- tions and organizations that are included in the recruitment marketing strategy. This includes the use of a diverse set of flexible resources that can be adjusted to meet variable recruitment needs (i.e., banners, table- cloths, E-mail content, etc.). (cid:

) Using standardized, high quality recruitment marketing materials to a consistent IRS brand message specifically tailored to attract identified, desirable candidate segments and market the IRS as an employer of choice. (cid:

) Maintaining relationships with job candidates throughout the recruitment cycle using established tracking systems and communication processes. Recruiting sources will be linked to qualified, diverse applicants to ing employees for continuous process evaluations and improvements. (cid:

) Tracking effectiveness and return on investment (ROI) of recruitment ties through continual analysis of performance metrics that are aligned to IRS and Human Capital Office(HCO) strategic goals. (cid:
) Incorporating continuous process evaluations and improvements into the recruitment strategy.
The mission of the IRS Recruitment Office (IRO) is to support the IRS recruit- ment goal of attracting the best candidates for IRS positions.
The IRO will accomplish its mission by: (cid:

) Establishing a data-driven annual recruiting plan, to include a single set of Service-wide recruiting targets. Targeted recruitment efforts (i.e., locations and/or candidates segments) will be based on long-term workforce needs and the efficient use of resources, and the annual ment plan will ensure EDI and diversity considerations are addressed. (cid:

) Partnering directly with all operating divisions and functional units HCO, EDI and IRS affinity groups to ensure that all recruitment efforts are incorporated or reflected in the corporate recruitment strategy. (cid:

) Strategically managing relationships with key contacts at gateway institu- tions and organizations that are included in the recruitment marketing strategy. This includes the use of a diverse set of flexible resources that can be adjusted to meet variable recruitment needs (i.e., banners, table- cloths, E-mail content, etc.). (cid:

) Using standardized, high quality recruitment marketing materials to a consistent IRS brand message specifically tailored to attract identified, desirable candidate segments and market the IRS as an employer of choice. (cid:

) Maintaining relationships with job candidates throughout the recruitment cycle using established tracking systems and communication processes. Recruiting sources will be linked to qualified, diverse applicants to ing employees for continuous process evaluations and improvements. (cid:

) Tracking effectiveness and return on investment (ROI) of recruitment ties through continual analysis of performance metrics that are aligned to IRS and Human Capital Office(HCO) strategic goals. (cid:
) Incorporating continuous process evaluations and improvements into the recruitment strategy.
(02-26-2010) IRS Recruitment Office Strategies and Objectives
) The IRS Recruitment Office is a branch of the Human Capital Office. (
) The IRO Director is the advisor to the Chief Human Capital on strategic Office ment issues. (
) Two branches report to the IRO Director: (cid:
) Media and Analysis Branch (cid:
) Relationship Management Branch (
) The IRO Media and Analysis Branch manages media and marketing with support provided by the Service’s employment marketing contract. Office and Media (

) A permanent media presence is vital to the continual improvement of the image as an employer of choice. The Media & Analysis Branch is Employment for strategically communicating the benefits of IRS employment to potential employees. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch designs employment marketing campaigns using the research, analysis, and design services available through the Design Service’s employment marketing contract. Campaign design activities conducting research using focus groups research, analyzing industry best practices, evaluating proposals, developing prototypes and final products, continually include media placement, job postings and direct marketing nents, all of which support the IRS Careers Web at (www.jobs.irs.gov). (

) The IRS Careers Web at (www.jobs.irs.gov) is solely focused on marketing and recruitment, and contains links to the online vacancy ment and application systems. (The site is not used to distribute any tax- on the related information). The site is hosted on a secure server controlled by the IRS information systems organization. Strategic media campaigns direct audiences to the IRS Careers Web, which provides links to all approved internet sites. (

) The IRS Career Explorer Game Room a subset of the IRS Careers Web is hosted on a commercial internet game server and accessed through links the IRS Careers Web site. The IRS Career Explorer Game Room features teractive games that provide education and career information to site (
) IRS Careers Island is a simulation inside the Second Life virtual world operated by Linden Labs. Second Life is an Internet-based virtual world launched in

A downloadable client program allows users, to interact using graphic avatars, providing an advanced social networking service. Careers Island operations portray the IRS as a progressive employer in this extremely viral social networking environment.

) The Media and Analysis Branch maintains a base level of advertising in national print publications including professional journals, college Print Media publications including professional journals, college recruitment diversity-focused publications, special-interest publications, and leisure magazines. Print media campaigns can reflect nationwide employment tunities, or may be targeted to specific jobs and/or locations. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch maintains a base level of advertising on internet, including professional organization sites, college recruitment sites, Internet Media general recruitment sites, diversity-focused sites, special interest sites, and general interest sites. Internet media campaigns can reflect nationwide ment opportunities, or may be targeted to specific jobs and/or locations. (

) Placements are purchased on job posting and career information sites for during the campaign year. These job postings supplement, but do not official job posting on USAJOBS. The Media and Analysis Branch posting job announcements and career information to selected sites. (

) Subscriptions for opt-in E-mail and text message broadcasts (direct are purchased from service providers through the Service’s employment marketing contractor. The Media and Analysis Branch manages the E-mail text message broadcasts as well as the responses. (

) The IRO maintains a presence at career fairs and other venues where ment materials may be displayed and/or distributed. Recruiting materials Employment also be made available for placement in local newspapers and other Materials (

) The Media and Analysis Branch is responsible for the design, procurement distribution of recruitment displays for IRS. Additional copies of the national Displays displays and additional photo-panels may be purchased by operating and functional units through the Service’s recruitment marketing and ing contract. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch uses brand management to market the an employer of choice. The IRS brand reflects values, vision and mission Marketing the Service. Standardized recruitment marketing materials deliver a and message and are used across the IRS. Content within branded materials be tailored to attract identified candidates segments. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch maintains an inventory of employment marketing handouts and brochures. These materials are designed by the Service’s recruitment marketing and advertising contractor, published by Publishing Services, and warehoused in national distribution centers. Corporate recruiters and local recruitment offices can order handouts and brochures from the national distribution centers. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch procures and maintains an inventory of motional items (giveaways) for distribution at recruitment events by Items recruiters. The giveaways contain at a minimum the IRS brand message the IRS Careers Web address, www.jobs.irs.gov. No.

Recruitment Strategies 6.332.1
Strategic (

) The Media and Analysis Branch is responsible for the creation and mainte- nance of an inventory of media templates that can be adapted for local use Print operating divisions and functional units. These templates contain approved graphics and employer branding messages. Local job titles, salaries, grades, locations, and contact information for local offices can be inserted in the approved media templates as needed. Operating divisions and functional are responsible for the placement of ads in local advertising outlets. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch is responsible for producing baseline thirty- second commercials (background video, audio, and employer branding). The national contractor inserts local job titles, salary, grades, locations, and Advertising information for local offices. Operating divisions and functional units are re- sponsible for working with Communication & Liaison Media Relations to place customized commercials with local television outlets. (

) The Media and Analysis Branch is responsible for producing baseline radio that can be adapted by local offices and advertising contractors. Radio ads Radio produced in ten-second, thirty-second and sixty-second lengths. The baseline ad includes background audio, employer branding, and a script for inserting local job titles, salary ranges, grade levels, locations, and contact information. Operating divisions and functional units are responsible for working with Com- munications & Liaison Media Relations to place customized commercials with local radio outlets. (

) Each fall, the Media and Analysis Branch provides recruitment advertising to help fill thousands of seasonal and temporary jobs during the tax filing season Campus (primarily in Submission Processing centers). In addition to the usual print Campaigns Internet media, the Media and Analysis Branch uses a wide range of tools developed specifically for individual campuses (e.g., local flyers, transit ads, cinema ads, cup sleeves, billboards, radio ads, and direct mail campaigns, etc.). (

) The Media and Analysis Branch maintains a permanent planning and analysis function within the IRO to set recruitment targets based on operating divisions Office and functional units’ forecasted hiring needs. The annual corporate recruiting Analysis plan takes into consideration IRS resource needs, EDI and diversity consider- ations, contingency plans and execution of the recruitment strategy against plan. (

) The annual corporate recruiting plan is created jointly with IRS stakeholders. Primary stakeholders include representatives from offices within HCO, hiring coordinators representing operating divisions and functional units, and Office Equity Diversity and Inclusion(EDI) representatives. In addition, the Media and Analysis Branch partners with managers, HR specialists, and other organiza- tion stakeholders to review and analyze each division’s specific hiring needs ensure that recruitment efforts remain in sync with evolving hiring projections and diversity needs. (Communication occurs on a quarterly basis, at In some cases, members of IRS affinity groups and/or representatives from Communication & Liaison National Public Liaison (NPL) participate in the dis- cussions.

Recruitment Strategies 6.332.1

The IRS Recruitment Office performance management system ties recruitment success to HCO and IRS strategic goals. The Media and Analysis Branch conducts studies and analyzes data for use in measuring the success of each recruitment source. Return on Investment (ROI) targets will vary for each source strategy. The IRO measures the cost of a source strategy against re
cruitment success and utilizes various performance measures to gauge the effectiveness of recruitment efforts.

3. Recruiting conversion rate (recruited applications/touched)

) The IRS attracts talent for hard-to-fill occupations and/or locations by effec- tively utilizing the corporate recruiters, event planning and relationship management. The Relationship Management Branch within the IRS Recruiting Office is responsible for attracting and recruiting the best candidates. The Re- lationship Management plans an annual calendar of recruiting events, which reflects budgetary and cost considerations and return on investment. (
) The Relationship Management Branch oversees the following program areas within the IRO:

) The Relationship Management Branch is responsible for the recruiting, selecting, hiring, supporting and managing of a diverse staff of full-time corporate recruiters who market the IRS mission and its careers. Corporate recruiters build strategic relationships with key partnership organizations including, but not limited to, colleges, universities, and IRS affinity groups. Corporate recruiters coordinate with IRS field and campus executive as well senior and frontline managers in a team-based approach to plan and implement recruitment events. (
) Corporate recruiters are responsible for: (cid:
) Maintaining recruiting relationships with colleges and universities (cid:
) Initiating and maintaining contact with professional organizations, IRS affinity groups, stakeholder liaisons and community organizations to execute annual recruiting initiatives (cid:
) Conducting and attending recruiting events (cid:
) Working cooperatively with IRS executives and representatives to presence at recruiting events and use of consistent messaging (cid:
) Identifying and communicating with candidates (cid:
) Maintaining recruitment event and contact information using the recruiter candidate tracking system (

) Corporate recruiters are responsible for representing the recruiting needs of IRS operating divisions and functional units. They work closely with the embedded recruitment offices of all IRS operating divisions and functional units. (

) The Relationship Management Branch is responsible for providing annual recruiter training. All full-time corporate recruiters are required to complete annual training. Training topics include, but are not limited to, the following: (cid:
) Recruitment functions, roles and responsibilities in the recruiting process (cid:
) Use of corporate brand and targeted candidate messages (cid:
) Hiring authorities (cid:
) Candidate tracking systems (cid:
) Applicant system updates and enhancements (cid:
) Communication plans and practices with operating divisions and units and executives (cid:
) Operating division and functional unit hiring plans and timelines (cid:
) Supporting IRS campus recruitment (cid:
) EDI and Diversity action plans (cid:
) Cultural awareness Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The IRS is committed to supporting the recruitment, hiring and retention of employees with targeted disabilities, as defined by the Office of Personnel A Recruitment Management (will add source and URL before final submitted here). The Recruitment Office partners with other HCO divisions, EDI, the Office of the Chief Accessibility Coordinator and IRS operating divisions and functional to deliver disability recruitment outreach activities and disabled veterans outreach efforts. The Relationship Management Branch is responsible for Schedule A program oversight on a Servicewide level. (

) The Relationship Management Branch partners with the Office of the Chief cessibility Coordinator to assist operating divisions and functional units in identifying individuals with targeted disabilities who are interested in a in the post of duty where a job is to be announced or projected vacancies scheduled to occur. The Relationship Management Branch supplements the Office of the Chief Accessibility Coordinator’s national contacts with Veterans organizations, regional and state Vocational Rehabilitation Centers and non- profit organizations to identify and recruit potential schedule A candidates. (
) The Relationship Management Branch supports the IRS initiative to increase the hiring of disabled employees through recruitment efforts including: (cid:

) The IRS is committed to supporting the recruitment, hiring and retention of U.S. veterans who are a good fit for the IRS based on skill sets and experiences acquired during their military tenure that are highly desirable transferable. The Relationship Management Branch is responsible for the veteran recruitment program. (

report and diversity focus as determined by EDI and OPERA for the fiscal year. EDI provides timely data on diversity recruit- ment needs to the IRS Recruitment Office, which is used to develop a schedule of marketing, media and recruitment events, that will help achieve IRS recruitment plan. (

) The Relationship Management Branch develops relationships with colleges and universities as a key component to recruiting applicants at the and early-career level. Recruitment activities at selected colleges and ties include participating in job fairs, making classroom presentations, ads in student newspaper and E-mail blasts to students. The Relationship Management Branch maintains a focused approached to college recruitment using a tiered system of school relationships identifying colleges and ties as core, priority or other. Recruitment strategies for college and events are adjusted on an annual basis through activities including a review the tiered list of colleges and universities, ROI assessment, and feedback IRS stakeholders and corporate recruiters. (

) The Relationship Management Branch focuses its recruiting and marketing efforts at core schools the top accredited colleges and universities in ing, business, tax and scientific fields whose diverse student populations targeted skill sets that are a good fit for IRS occupations. Corporate partner with IRS executives to develop a relationship with each core school. (

) The IRS builds relationships with career counselors and, in high-volume years, has an increased attendance in job fairs and other campus events at additional colleges and universities known as priority schools. (

) The Relationship Management Branch engages in recruitment efforts at colleges and universities where the IRS has successfully recruited in the Efforts at these schools will supplement those at the core and priority particularly when recruitment efforts must be increased to facilitate large initiatives or hiring for a specific location. (

) The executive recruitment sponsor program engages IRS leaders in the re- cruitment process. By participating in the recruitment process with support corporate recruiters, executives help develop and maintain relationships that allow IRS to identify and cultivate top-quality candidates. (

) The Relationship Management Branch oversees recruitment teams of corporate recruiters and IRS executives, which develop personal at targeted colleges and universities, attend recruiting events and participate targeted outreach to student groups and professors. Outreach activities may include, but not limited to, developing intern pools, making early job commit- ments or pursuing mentor programs. (

) IRS Executives participating in the recruitment sponsor program are asked participate in a minimum of one recruitment activity per semester (Fall and Spring), which coincides with peak hiring seasons. (
) IRS Executives are encouraged to inspire and motivate IRS leaders and employees to participate with corporate recruiters as the face of the IRS. (
) IRS Executives are asked to promote active and planned recruitment with key IRS leaders and executives. Internal Revenue Manual
6.332.1.7.8.1 (02-26-2010) Core, Priority and Other Schools

The Relationship Management Branch engages in recruitment efforts at colleges and universities where the IRS has successfully recruited in the past. Efforts at these schools will supplement those at the core and priority schools, particularly when recruitment efforts must be increased to facilitate large hiring initiatives or hiring for a specific location.
Strategic (
) IRS Executives are also welcome to pursue recruiting relationships with targeted professional associations and IRS affinity groups. (

) Corporate recruiters help executives develop a personal and lasting relation- ship with the leadership at their assigned college or university, and keep Recruiter colleges or universities informed about IRS careers and up-to-date job nity information. Corporate recruiters work with IRS executives to establish a strategy for meeting recruitment targets. (

) Corporate recruiters research and create opportunities for executives to pate in a variety of recruitment activities at their assigned college or Corporate recruiters handle all event logistics, scheduling and policy matters. In addition, corporate recruiters capture and report information about the ex- ecutive/school relationship and recruitment activities. (

) The Relationship Management Branch provides collaborative recruiting all operating divisions and functional units. Each operating division and func- Division and tional unit provides annual hiring needs to the IRS Recruitment Office in a Unit timely manner to enable the IRO to create a calendar of events and the in recruitment plan. (

) Operating divisions and functional units provide recruitment representatives assist corporate recruiters at events as requested. Assistance may include attending recruitment events, making presentations to targeted organizations and communicating with potential candidates. Feedback on recruitment activi- ties provided by recruitment representatives will be considered in the development of the annual recruitment plan and recruitment calendar of events. (

) Requests to represent the IRS at recruitment events that are received directly by the operating divisions and functional units should be shared with the local in corporate recruiter, who can provide logistics, planning and scheduling Events Recruitment events may include speeches and presentations to students, of the fessional organizations, affinity groups or the general public. (

) Service-wide policy requires close coordination with Criminal Investigation Special Agent part-time recruiters and IRO corporate recruiters to ensure the with IRS is represented as one agency at events. The Relationship Management Branch supports CI hiring through recruitment outreach efforts and on recruitment event participation (i.e., sharing booths). In addition, the Rela- tionship Management Branch provides standardized marketing and media materials for recruitment activities. (

) The IRS has established relationships with professional associations and nizations throughout the country that are excellent channels for reaching and diverse applicants of all ages, especially those in mid-career who have specialized experience. The Relationship Management Branch shares IRS re- cruitment messages with these external institutions. The Relationship Management Branch centrally manages these relationships through corporate recruiters and relationship managers that handle the administrative and logistics of recruitment. Servicewide representatives serve as the face of the IRS to candidates. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

cruitment messages with these external institutions. The Relationship Management Branch centrally manages these relationships through corporate recruiters and relationship managers that handle the administrative and logistics of recruitment. Servicewide representatives serve as the face of the IRS to candidates.
Recruitment Strategies 6.332.1
page 11

The Communication & Liaison National Public (NPL) provides the Management Branch access to professional associations at the national level. NPL shares and receives information and resources with partners like organi- zations for tax professionals, state society of CPAs state bar associations and other professional accounting and tax associations. The Relationship ment Branch partners with NPL to deliver IRS corporate recruiting messages during partner activities to provide up-to-date IRS career opportunities and hiring process information. The IRS campus recruitment will remain primarily with campus personnel. IRO will provide support to the campus recruiting efforts. The Relationship Management Branch Support will oversee campus recruiting support through the following: (cid:
) Working with the IRO Marketing & Media function create effective campus marketing materials and provide corporate advertising funding and materials (cid:
) Coordinating cross-campus information sharing (cid:
) Highlighting campus hiring needs in communication with colleges and affinity groups (cid:
) Building relationships with campus-relevant professional associations such as contact service representative associations (cid:
) Helping campus Personnel staff collect, synthesize, and act upon IRS Re- cruitment Office performance metric (cid:
) Helping refine recruitment strategy for attracting high-quality and diverse candidates

) The IRS will maintain relationships with candidates throughout the process and track successful applicants through the first years of their IRS career. This section provides an overview of the systems used to maintain these relationships. Process (

) R-Trak is a stand alone database used by the recruiters to System track cruiting events and candidates from initial contact through applied and status. Each recruiter is responsible for inputting data into the system. Data uploaded on a regular basis to be consolidated into a single database. matches are done based on the uploaded data. The consolidated database downloaded to each recruiter within one week. (
) The IRS will convert R-Trak to a web-based system in Peopl
rak to meet short-term IRS needs. Peopl
rak is a web-based system used to track plans, actual hires and space needs. R-Trak contact names are matched hire names from Peopl
rak to show how many R-Trak contacts were R-Trak contact records are updated with information captured from Hire from Peopl
rak. (

) Career Connector is the online application system used by the HR Connect and Treasury Department, including the IRS R-Trak contact names are and Career matched with applicant names to show how many R-Trak contacts applied through Career Connector. The IRS will maintain relationships with candidates throughout the recruitment process and track successful applicants through the first years of their IRS career. This section provides an overview of the systems used to maintain these relationships.
Career Connector is the online application system used by the HR Connect and Treasury Department, including the IRS R

to

with the IRS as a candidate, throughout the applicant and hiring stages, to being hired, and then to performance data and/or attrition. (
) The IRS utilizes various Federal Hiring Flexibility to hire college and students, including: (cid:
) Federal Career Intern Program (FCIP) (cid:

) Presidential Management Fellows (PMF) The IRS will further capitalize on non-traditional intake channels to hire students and recent graduates. These programs will be used to hire locations where the competitive process does not render sufficient and/or attract a more diversified workforce (
) The IRS Recruitment Office supports expanded use of the Excellent Get Early Recruitment Offers (EAGER) program, which allows the agency extend early job offers to candidates. (

) The IRS also promotes the appropriate use of non-traditional intake for veterans and people with disabilities. The IRS Recruitment Office managers and hiring coordinators within operating divisions and functional units to understand the appropriate use of non-traditional recruitment intake programs. (

) Programs are being developed that will facilitate interactions between and provide managers in an effort to expose students to IRS career ties and to encourage them to apply for positions upon graduation. This will allow IRS to compete for candidates who might otherwise be lost to other employers. (
